instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
Hi, first time poster, thank you for everything you guys do here.

I have [B]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/B] that had water spilled through the keyboard. The visible damage/corrosion on the Logic Board was minimal.

The only visible damage was located around the CPU/GPU Phase chips (<CHIP>U7220</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7230</CHIP>, QA340).. again very minimal, small amounts of white corrosion/oxidation.

All ports show [B]20v[/B] with [B]0A[/B] draw.

The only thermal activity on the board is the T2 and corresponding charging chips warming up.
                       
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.6v                           
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> - 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> - 12.6v

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v
[I]*Resistance measurements match good board on all CPU lines listed above*[/I]

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> - 0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL>- 3.3v




Please note the following:
1. I have tested all the lines that show up as 0v for shorts to ground and all line readings match good board.
2. I attempted T2 revive after cleaning visible corrosion and I get error [B]code 4010[/B], the fans go [B]full[/B] speed after failed T2 revive.
3. I replaced [B]<CHIP>U7210</CHIP>[/B], [B]<CHIP>U7220</CHIP>[/B], [B]<CHIP>U7230</CHIP>[/B] and attempted T2 revive again and it still failed with 4010 and I still get 0V on all CPU rails
4. I understand board may fall into the "[I]brain dead[/I]" category, however I want to cover all my bases and learn potential additional troubleshooting methods I could apply in this situation. It feels like the board should be repairable as the liquid damage was visibly very minimal.

Thank you for your time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Can look as minimal, but liquid on the CPU power supplies can be letal!

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?
Check if all SSD power rails are good.
Keep in mind, T2 and Touchbar have dedicated partitions on the SSD.
SSD voltages must appear very soon on T2 boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
Thank you very much for the response.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is [B]1mv[/B] - I checked for short to ground and the line has a normal diode reading. Looks like <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> creates <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

0v9 NAND - 0.9v
1v8 NAND - 1.8v
2v5 NAND - 2.5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
Do you know which macOS version is on T2 machine?
Apple Configurator 2 MUST be executed on the same version.
You can try DFU from Catalina, as Big Sur too.
We have a good tutoeial linked on the forum...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message: Yea, I tried T2 revive on Catalina and Big Sur, I get the same error 4010. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
Try using another network connection.
Disable router firewall.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message: Same result, also not sure if it matters but I have successfully revived many T2's on my main internet connection. Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
You can try to reflash <CHIP>U4770</CHIP> (SoC ROM).
Need a dump from other similar board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
Hi thanks again for your support.

I now have a ROM reader, I have a good ROM dump from a good <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.

Is the data at jeopardy if the ROM dump has the wrong serial number/UUID?

Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot, liquid damage.
threads.message:
Try and see what happens.
I cannot confirm that is a problem caused by the SoC ROM however.
